questions.text: When is World AIDS day observed?
questions.solution:
The World AIDS Day is observed on December 1st. The theme for 2021 is 'Ending the HIV epidemic: Equitable Access, Everyone’s Voice'.

Option A:  The World Tuberculosis Day is on March 24.

Option B:  The World Cancer Day is on February 4.

Option D: The World Malaria Day is on April 25.

questions.text: What are the most common modes of transmission of HIV in India in descending order?
questions.solution:
The most common mode of transmission of HIV in India is heterosexual transmission, followed by transplacental and homosexual contact, respectively.

The common modes of transmission of HIV are:

  • Heterosexual (83.7%)
  • Injecting drug users (5.6%)
  • Transplacental transmission (3.8 %)
  • Homosexual (2.5%)
  • Blood and blood products (0.8%)
  • Unknown (3.6%)

The highest risk of transmission is seen in homosexuals due to the increased risk of abrasions during anal sex.

questions.text: Health care workers will require post-exposure prophylaxis after exposure to which of the following body fluids of an HIV patient?
questions.solution:
Health care workers exposed to the menstrual blood of an HIV-positive patient will require post-exposure prophylaxis. The risk of transmission of HIV during vaginal intercourse is higher when the woman is menstruating.

Tears, non-blood-stained saliva, urine, and sweat do not pose a significant risk. Exposure to these fluids does not require post-exposure prophylaxis.

WHO recommends the dapivirine vaginal ring as a new choice for HIV prevention in high-risk women as part of combination prevention approaches. The ring works by releasing the antiretroviral drug dapivirine into the vagina slowly over 28 days.

questions.text: As per WHO staging of HIV, which of the following HIV-positive patients cannot be classified as stage IV?

choices.text: A 29-year-old man diagnosed with cerebral toxoplasmosis
A 56-year-old woman with significant weight loss and muscle wasting
A 43-year-old lady being treated for Pneumocystis pneumonia

questions.solution:
Oral candidiasis is seen in stage 3, not stage 4 of HIV.

The following conditions are included in the WHO stage IV of HIV:

  • HIV wasting syndrome (Slim disease)
  • HIV encephalopathy
  • HIV-associated nephropathy or cardiomyopathy
  • Infections:
    • Pneumocystis jiroveci pneumonia (previously known as Pneumocystis carinii)
    • Chronic herpes simplex infection, cytomegalovirus disease
    • Oesophageal/ tracheal candidiasis 
    • Extrapulmonary TB or disseminated M. avium infection
    • CNS toxoplasmosis
    • Extrapulmonary cryptococcosis
    • Chronic cryptosporidiosis or isosporiasis
    • Disseminated fungal infections (histoplasmosis, coccidioidomycosis)
    • Recurrent severe bacterial pneumonia or septicemia 
    • Atypical disseminated leishmaniasis
    • Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy
  • Neoplasms:
    • Kaposi sarcoma
    • Lymphoma (cerebral or B cell non-Hodgkin)
    • Invasive cervical carcinoma

Related Pearl: WHO clinical staging of HIV

Selected conditions & respective clinical stages in HIV  
Clinical stage 1
  • Asymptomatic
  • Persistent generalized lymphadenopathy
Clinical stage 2 (Mild Symptoms)
  • Moderate unexplained weight loss (<10% ofpresumed or measured body weight) 
  • Recurrent respiratory tract infections (sinusitis,tonsillitis, otitis media, pharyngitis) 
  • Herpes zoster       
  • Angular cheilitis       
  • Recurrent oral ulceration       
  • Papular pruritic eruption       
  • Fungal nail infections       
  • Seborrhoeic dermatitis       
  • Unexplained persistent hepatosplenomegaly*       
  • Extensive wart virus infection*       
  • Extensive molluscum contagiosum*       
  • Unexplained persistent parotid enlargement*

 *In Children

Clinical stage 3 & 4 represent Advanced & Severe illness respectively

For complete staging, please refer WHO guidelines.

questions.text: A 45-year man with a high-risk sexual history now presents with prolonged fever for the past 1.5 months. On examination, the following finding is noted. Which one of the following additional features is required to diagnose this patient with AIDS?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suspicious for HIV infection. As per the WHO definition, the presence of chronic diarrhea > 1 month is needed to diagnose this patient with AIDS.

The WHO clinical definition is used for AIDS surveillance in the clinical setting. Patients > 12 years of age are said to have AIDS if they have at least 2 major and 1 minor signs, provided other clinically similar conditions are be ruled out.

Major signs:

  • Weight loss ≥ 10% of body weight
  • Chronic diarrhea > 1 month
  • Prolonged fever for > 1 month (intermittent or constant)

Minor signs:

  • A persistent cough > 1 month
  • Generalized pruritic dermatitis
  • History of herpes zoster
  • Oropharyngeal candidiasis
  • Chronic progressive or disseminated herpes simplex infection
  • Generalized lymphadenopathy

For surveillance purposes, the presence of either of the following is also considered sufficient to diagnose AIDS:

  • Generalized Kaposi's sarcoma
  • Cryptococcal meningitis

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding the epidemiology of HIV?

choices.text: HIV infected infants and children do not progress rapidly to AIDS
Seminal secretions are more infectious than vaginal secretion
People are infectious during the window period
HIV prevalence has not exceeded 5% in any subpopulation

questions.solution:
Infants and children infected with HIV progress rapidly to AIDS. 

Semen is more infectious than vaginal or cervical fluids as it has a higher concentration of HIV.

HIV-infected patients are highly infectious during:

  • Window period (very early stages before antibody production) 
  • Advanced stages of infection (due to higher levels of viremia) 

 HIV prevalence has consistently remained < 5% in all defined subpopulations.

questions.text: In individuals exposed to HIV, within how many hours should prophylaxis be initiated?
questions.solution: Post-exposure prophylaxis for HIV should ideally be initiated within 72 hours. It is recommended that it be started as even as early as < 2 hours.

questions.text: A nurse sustained a needle stick injury while sampling the blood of a patient who is HIV-positive. Which of the following is incorrect?

choices.text: Washing hands with soap and water
Measure baseline viral markers of health care worker immediately

questions.solution:
Triple therapy (tenofovir 300mg + lamivudine 300mg + dolutegravir 50mg) is recommended for HIV post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP), not monotherapy. 

Steps to be undertaken after a needlestick injury are:

  • Wash the wound and skin with water and soap. Do not scrub and avoid antiseptics.
  • Assess exposed individual:
    • Check baseline viral markers
    • Monitor for acute seroconversion illness within 3-6 weeks after exposure
    • If testing is positive, refer to ART center 
  • Assess exposure source and determine the risk of transmission 
  • Counseling and support
  • Initiate PEP at the earliest - preferably < 2 hours and ideally < 72 hours
  • 28-day prescription with drug information
  • HIV test at 3 months after exposure

Related Pearl: WHO 2018 guidelines for post exposure prophylaxis regimen in HIV

An HIV post-exposure prophylaxis regimen with two ARV drugs is effective, but three drugs are preferred.

The recent MOHFW January 2020 guidelines on the management of PEP in HIV recommends the replacement of 2 drug regimen with 3 drug regimen referring to WHO December 2018 guidelines on PEP management protocol in HIV. This shift towards recommending a three-drug regimen for
everyone was based on the availability of less toxic and better-tolerated medications.

ADULTS AND ADOLESCENTS:-

Preferred backbone regimen - TDF + 3TC (or FTC)

New drug -  DTG is the preferred third drug for HIV post-exposure prophylaxis

New drug - ATV/r, DRV/r, LPV/r and RAL may be considered as alternative third drug options for post-exposure prophylaxis

CHILDREN:-

Preferred backbone regimen - AZT + 3TC

ABC + 3TC or TDF + 3TC (or FTC) can be considered as alternative regimens

New drug - DTG is the preferred third drug for HIV post-exposure prophylaxis

New drug - ATV/r, DRV/r, LPV/r and RAL may be considered as alternative third drug options for post-exposure prophylaxis

 

Legend

TDF - Tenofovir disoproxil fumarate 

3TC - Lamivudine

questions.text: Which of the following HIV-infected patients would you start on cotrimoxazole prophylaxis?

choices.text: A 24-year-old pregnant woman with WHO stage 2 disease.
A 47-year-old man in a malaria-endemic area with WHO stage 1 disease
A 2-week-old HIV-exposed infant who is being exclusively breastfed
A 7-year-old girl with a CD4 count of 400 cells/cubic mm

questions.solution:
All HIV infected adults and children in malaria-endemic areas should be given cotrimoxazole prophylaxis regardless of CD4 count or WHO clinical stage.

Cotrimoxazole is also indicated in areas with a low prevalence of malaria as shown below:

Age group Indication When to discontinue
HIV-exposed infants > 4-6 weeks of age All infants After HIV infection has been ruled out
Children < 5 years All children

At 5 years in areas with low prevalence of malaria 

(In high prevalence areas, continue till adulthood)
Children > 5 years CD4 count <350 and/or WHO stage 3/4 When CD4 > 350 and they have been on ART > 6 months
Adults and pregnant women CD4 count <350 and/or WHO stage 3/4 When CD4 count is rising and viral load is decreasing
HIV and TB coinfection  All patients —

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with HIV is being screened for symptoms of TB. He reports no cough, fever, night sweats, or weight loss. What is the next step in management?

choices.text: Start 5 mg/kg/day Isoniazid daily for 9 months
Prophylaxis does not need to be started
Start weekly dose of rifapentine + isoniazid for 3 months

questions.solution:
The next step in management in this patient is to provide tuberculosis preventive therapy (TPT) with rifapentine+ isoniazid weekly for 3 months.

According to the NTEP guidelines, TPT is indicated for the following groups:

      Risk group       Criteria 
  • People living with HIV
  • Negative 4 symptom test - start TPT after ruling out TB
  • Patients with active TB - start TPT after completion of the ATT regimen
  • Household contacts (HHC) of pulmonary TB patients  < 5 years
  • Start TPT after ruling out active TB
  • Household contacts of pulmonary TB patients  ≥ 5 years
  • Other risk groups:
  • Children/adults on immunosuppressive therapy
  • Patients on anti-TNF treatment
  • Patients on dialysis or post-transplantation
  • Patients with silicosis
  • First rule out active TB
  • Start TPT if IGRA or TST is positive with a normal chest x-ray

IGRA - interferon-gamma release assay; TST - tuberculin skin test; ATT - antituberculous therapy

Target Population Treatment option
  • People living with HIV (adults and children > 2 years)
  • HHC of pulmonary TB patients
  • 3-month weekly Isoniazid (300 mg) and Rifapentine (300 mg) in persons older than 2 years
  • Infants <12 months of age and Children < 2years of age with HIV
  • 6-months daily isoniazid (6H): 10 mg/kg/day

TPT is contraindicated under the following conditions:

  • Active TB
  • Active hepatitis
  • Peripheral neuropathy
  • Regular and heavy alcohol consumption

questions.text:
Which of the following is true about the 2025 targets of the Global AIDS Strategy for 2021 to 2026?

A. 95% of women of reproductive age must have their HIV and reproductive health needs met
B. 95% of pregnant/ breastfeeding women with HIV must have suppressed viral loads
C. 75% of HIV-exposed children must be tested at 2 months of age and after stopping breastfeeding
D. 90% of people living with HIV must receive preventive treatment for TB
E. 75% of children living with HIV must have suppressed viral loads by 2023
questions.solution:
95%, not 75% of HIV-exposed children are tested by 2 months of age and after stopping breastfeeding according to the 2025 targets.

Global AIDS Strategy 2021-2026 has the following targets for the year 2025:

90% of People living with HIV Preventive treatment for TB

Linked to services for overall health and wellbeing including:

  • Communicable and non-communicable diseases

questions.text: A 29-year-old man comes to you with complaints of painful swelling in his right groin, as shown below. He gives a history of 3-4 painless ulcers over his penis 4 weeks ago that had resolved on its own. What is the likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario and image showing the groove sign of Greenblatt are suggestive of lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV). The causative organism is Chlamydia trachomatis. 

LGV commonly presents with multiple small, painless ulcers on the genitalia that are often unrecognized and resolve spontaneously. This is followed by painful lymphadenopathy and bubo formation after 4-6 weeks. If left untreated, it can lead to extensive lymphatic damage, elephantiasis, and deformity of the genitalia.

The treatment of choice is doxycycline.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of case detection in STDs?
questions.solution:
Notification is not part of the case detection strategy for STDs. Case detection in STDs includes the following:

  • Screening
  • Contact tracing
  • Cluster testing

questions.text: A 32-year-old man is diagnosed with syphilis. On probing, he gives you the information of other people in the same sociosexual environment as him. You then refer all these people for testing. What is this method of case detection?
questions.solution:
This method of case detection is known as cluster testing.

The methods employed in case detection of STDs are:

  • Screening - testing of apparently healthy volunteers from the general population for early detection of disease
  • Contact tracing - technique by which the sexual partners of diagnosed patients are identified, located, investigated, and treated
  • Cluster testing - patients are asked to name other persons who move in the same socio-sexual environment, who are then tested

questions.text: A 29-year-old man with urethral discharge is treated with the grey kit. This treatment is effective for the control of which of the following organisms?
questions.solution:
The grey kit is effective for the treatment of infections caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae and Chlamydia trachomatis.

Related Pearl: Syndromic Management of Sexually Transmitted Infections

Partner Management when asymptomatic is not required for Gardenella vaginalis, Candida and Herpes infections.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about the epidemiology of leprosy?

choices.text: Increased prevalence in childhood indicates that the disease is active and spreading.
Multibacillary cases are the most infectious in the community
Bacterial load is highest in patients with tuberculoid leprosy
Seldom may be transmitted by insect vectors

questions.solution:
The bacterial load is highest in patients with lepromatous leprosy. 1 gram of leproma contains as many as 2-7 billion bacilli.

Multibacillary cases (lepromatous and borderline lepromatous) are the most important source of infection in the community. Infection can occur at any age. In general, cases rise to a peak between 10-20 years of age and then fall. In endemic areas, the disease is acquired commonly during childhood. A high prevalence in this age group indicates that the disease is active and spreading.

The organism may also be transmitted by insect vectors or by tattooing needles. However, this is not clinically significant.

questions.text: Elimination of leprosy in India is defined as the prevalence of :
questions.solution: Elimination of leprosy in India is defined as a prevalence of < 1 per 10,000.

questions.text: What is the prevalence of leprosy in India per 10,000?
questions.solution: The prevalence of leprosy in India is 0.41 per 10,000 as of March 2021.

questions.text: The Ridley Jopling classification for leprosy uses which of the following parameters?
questions.solution:
The Ridley Jopling classification uses clinical, bacteriological, immunological, and histological parameters.

questions.text:
A pathologist is studying the split skin smears taken from 4 sites of a leprosy patient. The following findings are noted in the samples. What is the bacteriological index?

Sample 1 - 10 bacilli in 100 oil immersion fields

Sample 2 - > 1000 bacilli in each oil immersion field

Sample 3 - 10 bacilli in 100 oil immersion fields

Sample 4 - > 1000 bacilli in each oil immersion field
questions.solution:
The bacteriological index (BI) of the given samples is 3.5

According to Ridley’s logarithmic scale,   

  • 10 bacilli out of 100 oil immersion fields indicate an index of 1+
  • > 1000 bacilli out of average fields imply an index of 6+ 

The bacteriological index is calculated by adding the index from each site examined and dividing the total by the number of sites examined.

Hence, BI = (1+1+6+6) / 4

BI = 14/4

BI = 3.5

Related Pearl: Ridley's logarithmic scale in determining Bacterial Index

Bacterial Index(BI) indicates the density of the leprosy bacilli in smears and includes both living and dead bacilli.

According to Ridley's logarithmic scale, the range is from 0 to 6+ and is based on the number of bacilli seen in an average microscopic field of the smear using an oil-immersion objective.

0

No bacilli in any of the 100 oil-immersion field

1+

1-10 bacilli, on average, in 100 oil-immersion field

2+

1-10 bacilli, on average, in 10 oil-immersion field

3+

1-10 bacilli, on average, in each oil-immersion field

4+

10-100 bacilli, on average, in each oil-immersion field

5+

100-1000 bacilli, on average, in each oil-immersion field 

6+

More than 1000 bacilli, on average, in each oil-immersion field 

BI is calculated by adding up the index from each site examined and dividing the total by the number of sites examined.

questions.text: The lepromin test was performed on a patient with suspected leprosy. When will you ask him to come back for interpretation of the test results?
questions.solution:
The patient should be asked to come back after 48 hours and on the 21st day for interpretation of the test results.

The lepromin test is a skin test for delayed hypersensitivity and is the only method to study immunity in leprosy patients. It is performed by injecting 0.1ml of lepromin reagent intradermally into the inner aspect of the forearm. The following 2 reactions are observed:

Early reaction of Fernandez Late reaction of Mitsuda
Develops in 24-48 hours  Starts at 7-10 days, peaks at 3-4 weeks (read on day 21)
Remains for 3-5 days Gradually subsides over the next few weeks
Poorly defined erythema and induration. Carries less significance Considered positive if there is a nodule > 5 mm in diameter

questions.text: Which of the following is false about the lepromin test?

choices.text: It is negative in most children in the first 4 months of life
It can be used as a diagnostic test
It is used to classify leprosy cases
False positive may be seen in those who underwent BCG vacination

questions.solution:
The lepromin test is not a diagnostic test. It is only used to assess the immune status, classify the cases, and estimate the prognosis.

The two main drawbacks of this test are: 

  1. False-positive results in those who received BCG vaccination
  2. False-negative results in lepromatous and borderline lepromatous cases

questions.text: A group of public health workers is trying to identify trachoma cases at an ophthalmology camp. Which of the following is the best index to assess for trachoma inflammation?

choices.text: Follicles on the upper tarsal conjuctiva
Vascular pannus at the superior limbus

questions.solution:
In epidemiological studies, the upper tarsal conjunctiva is the best index of trachomatous inflammation in the eye.

For the purpose of diagnosis, any 2 of the following diagnostic criteria must be present:

  • Follicles on the upper tarsal conjunctiva
  • Limbal follicles and Herbert's pits
  • Typical conjunctival scarring (trichiasis and entropion)
  • Vascular pannus, most marked at the superior limbus

 The following image shows follicles on the upper tarsal conjunctiva seen in trachomatous inflammation.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the organisms causing trachoma?

choices.text: Morax- Axenfeld bacillus is the most widespread
Gonococcus is the most dangerous organism contributing to the disease process
Koch-Weeks bacillus is the most innocuous
C. trachomatis type D commonly causes permanent visual damage

questions.solution:
Gonococcus is the most dangerous organism contributing to the disease process in trachoma.

Classic endemic trachoma is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis types A, B, C.  Other pathogenic organisms that contribute to the disease process are: 

  • Morax-Axenfeld diplobacillus - most innocuous
  • Kochs-Weeks bacillus - most widespread
  • Gonococcus - most dangerous

The types D-K of C. trachomatis are sexually transmitted and cause inclusion conjunctivitis. It rarely causes permanent vision loss.

questions.text: The elimination of neonatal tetanus is defined as:
questions.solution:
The elimination of neonatal tetanus is defined as <1 case per 1000 live births in every district. Maternal and neonatal tetanus (MNT) was eliminated in India in 2015.

Since July 2018, TT vaccines have been replaced by the Td vaccine for dual protection.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is called the 8th day disease?
questions.solution:
Neonatal tetanus is known as the 8th-day disease. This is because the clinical features are often seen after the 7th day after birth due to infection of the umbilical cord.

Option A: Trench fever is also called the 5-day fever.

Option B: Pertussis is called the 100-day cough.

Option D: Scarlet fever is also known as the 2nd disease.

questions.text: A 13-year-old girl is brought to the casualty a few hours after being injured by a rusty knife. According to her parents, her course of tetanus vaccination was completed 7 years ago. What is the next best step in management?

choices.text: Human tetanus immunoglobulin and single dose of toxoid

questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of a contaminated wound in a patient who received complete immunization against tetanus 7 years ago. She comes under category B of tetanus immunization and must be given a single dose of tetanus toxoid alone.

The WHO recommends a 3-dose primary vaccination series with tetanus-diphtheria-containing vaccine followed by 3 booster doses. Ideally, there should be at least 4 years between booster doses.

Related Pearl: Post exposure prophylaxis for tetanus

Prophylaxis is given based on patient category:

A. Full immunization or a booster dose within the past 5 years.

B. Full immunization or a booster dose > 5 years ago but < 10 years.

C. Full immunization or a booster dose > 10 years ago.

D. Unknown or never taken immunization

Category Clean wound Unclean wound
A Only wound care Only wound care
B Wound care + TT single dose Wound care + TT single dose
C Wound care + TT single dose Wound care + TT single dose + Human tetanus immunoglobulin 
D Wound care + TT complete course Wound care + TT complete course + Human tetanus immunoglobulin
